articles.headline: Yellen Says China Trade Deal Has ‘Hurt American Consumers’
articles.snippet: The Treasury secretary said an agreement made by the Trump administration, which remains under review, had failed to address fundamental problems between the two countries.
articles.abstract: The Treasury secretary said an agreement made by the Trump administration, which remains under review, had failed to address fundamental problems between the two countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen has cast doubt on the merits of the trade agreement between the United States and China, arguing that it has failed to address the most pressing disputes between the world’s two largest economies and warning that the tariffs that remain in place have harmed American consumers.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Biden Faces New Pressure on Immigration
articles.snippet: A monthly surge in migrants and a ruling against a program that protects young immigrants underscored the difficult choices the president is confronting on an issue that could shape his legacy.
articles.abstract: A monthly surge in migrants and a ruling against a program that protects young immigrants underscored the difficult choices the president is confronting on an issue that could shape his legacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden came under renewed pressure on immigration Friday as the authorities said the largest number of migrants in years arrived at the border with Mexico last month and a federal judge in Texas raised legal questions about an Obama-era program that protects young immigrants from deportation.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Eileen Sullivan

articles.headline: European Floods Are Latest Sign of a Global Warming Crisis
articles.snippet: Floods like these, which have left more than 100 dead, had not been seen in perhaps 1,000 years. For many, the warnings came too late, raising questions about lapses in Germany’s flood alert system.
articles.abstract: Floods like these, which have left more than 100 dead, had not been seen in perhaps 1,000 years. For many, the warnings came too late, raising questions about lapses in Germany’s flood alert system.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Days before roiling waters tore through western Germany, a European weather agency issued an “extreme” flood warning after detailed models showed storms that threatened to send rivers surging to levels that a German meteorologist said on Friday had not been seen in 500 or even 1,000 years.
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy, Jack Ewing, Megan Specia and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: ‘Rogue’ U.S. Agency Used Racial Profiling to Investigate Commerce Dept. Employees, Report Says
articles.snippet: An obscure federal office operated for more than a decade as an “unaccountable police force” inside the Commerce Department, using extreme and unauthorized tactics.
articles.abstract: An obscure federal office operated for more than a decade as an “unaccountable police force” inside the Commerce Department, using extreme and unauthorized tactics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Officials in a little-known security unit within the Commerce Department conducted unauthorized surveillance and investigations into the agency’s employees that targeted people of Chinese and Middle Eastern descent, Senate investigators said in a new report.

articles.headline: In Texas, Top Two Republicans Steer Ship of State Hard to the Right
articles.snippet: Different in style and background, Gov. Greg Abbott and Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick have come together, for different reasons, to push an uncompromising conservative agenda.
articles.abstract: Different in style and background, Gov. Greg Abbott and Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick have come together, for different reasons, to push an uncompromising conservative agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: One is a former State Supreme Court justice who acts with a lawyer’s caution; the other a Trumpist firebrand who began his political career in the world of conservative talk radio. They have sparred at times, most recently this winter over the deadly failure of their state’s electrical grid.

articles.headline: As Lebanon Collapses, the Man With an Iron Grip on Its Finances Faces Questions
articles.snippet: People can’t get their money from banks, the currency has crashed and Riad Salameh’s reign at the central bank is facing allegations of fraud.
articles.abstract: People can’t get their money from banks, the currency has crashed and Riad Salameh’s reign at the central bank is facing allegations of fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For decades, Riad Salameh, Lebanon’s central bank chief, was lauded at home and abroad as a financial wizard who kept the economy running and the currency stable despite wars, assassinations and frequent political turmoil.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Collapse Raises New Fears About Florida’s Shaky Insurance Market
articles.snippet: Insurers were already skittish after losses from repeated hurricanes. The recent condo collapse has brought new insecurity. How long will Florida’s coast be insurable?
articles.abstract: Insurers were already skittish after losses from repeated hurricanes. The recent condo collapse has brought new insecurity. How long will Florida’s coast be insurable?
articles.lead_paragraph: Steve Rosenthal escaped with his life when his condo building in Florida crumbled and left him homeless last month, but he still owes more than $100,000 on his mortgage.
articles.byline: By Christopher Flavelle, Patricia Mazzei and Giulia Heyward

articles.headline: In Undervaccinated Arkansas, Covid Upends Life All Over Again
articles.snippet: While much of the nation tiptoes toward normalcy, the coronavirus is again swamping hospitals in places like Mountain Home, in a rural county where fewer than one-third of residents are vaccinated.
articles.abstract: While much of the nation tiptoes toward normalcy, the coronavirus is again swamping hospitals in places like Mountain Home, in a rural county where fewer than one-third of residents are vaccinated.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN HOME, Ark. — When the boat factory in this leafy Ozark Mountains city offered free coronavirus vaccinations this spring, Susan Johnson, 62, a receptionist there, declined the offer, figuring she was protected as long as she never left her house without a mask.

articles.headline: U.S. Habit of Backing Strongman Allies Fed Turmoil in Haiti
articles.snippet: Washington dismissed warnings that democracy was unraveling under President Jovenel Moïse, leaving a gaping leadership void after his assassination.
articles.abstract: Washington dismissed warnings that democracy was unraveling under President Jovenel Moïse, leaving a gaping leadership void after his assassination.
articles.lead_paragraph: As protesters hurled rocks outside Haiti’s national palace and set fires on the streets to demand President Jovenel Moïse’s resignation, President Trump invited him to Mar-a-Lago in 2019, posing cheerfully with him in one of the club’s ornate entryways.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Michael Crowley

articles.headline: The Pandemic Safety Net Is Coming Apart. Now What?
articles.snippet: The eviction moratorium expires at the end of the month. Unemployment enhancements after that. And then the student loan pause, food stamp provisions and more. Here’s advice on how to cope.
articles.abstract: The eviction moratorium expires at the end of the month. Unemployment enhancements after that. And then the student loan pause, food stamp provisions and more. Here’s advice on how to cope.
articles.lead_paragraph: One by one, pandemic relief programs that financially supported millions of Americans are going away.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Ron Lieber

articles.headline: OPEC Plus Agrees on Oil Production Increase, Easing Pressure on Supplies and Prices
articles.snippet: The pact clears the way for the group to pump more oil as global economies revive from pandemic lockdowns.
articles.abstract: The pact clears the way for the group to pump more oil as global economies revive from pandemic lockdowns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Major oil producers reached a deal on Sunday to increase production, a move that could help ease the pressure on gas prices and inflation as economies around the world recover after pandemic lockdowns.

articles.headline: Historically Black Colleges Finally Get the Spotlight
articles.snippet: There are star hirings and hundreds of millions in donations. But not every institution is sharing in the bounty, and some are struggling to survive.
articles.abstract: There are star hirings and hundreds of millions in donations. But not every institution is sharing in the bounty, and some are struggling to survive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Historically Black colleges and universities are having a moment, one that many educators say is more than a century overdue.

articles.headline: The Ascension of Ron Klain
articles.snippet: President Biden’s chief of staff worked his whole career to reach the corner office of the West Wing. He says he’s just a “staff person,” but Republicans call him “Prime Minister Klain.”
articles.abstract: President Biden’s chief of staff worked his whole career to reach the corner office of the West Wing. He says he’s just a “staff person,” but Republicans call him “Prime Minister Klain.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ron Klain, who after a few near misses finally achieved his career-long goal of becoming the White House chief of staff, will turn 60 this summer. This is, as his boss might say, a big deal.

articles.headline: ‘Historical Distortions’ Test South Korea’s Commitment to Free Speech
articles.snippet: Conspiracy theories about the country’s turbulent past have spread online. Now the government is pushing criminal penalties to crack down on misinformation.
articles.abstract: Conspiracy theories about the country’s turbulent past have spread online. Now the government is pushing criminal penalties to crack down on misinformation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL — In the history of South Korea’s fight for democracy, the 1980 uprising in Gwangju stands out as one of the proudest moments. Thousands of ordinary citizens took to the streets to protest a military dictatorship, and hundreds were shot down by security forces. The bloody incident has been sanctified in textbooks as the “Gwangju Democratization Movement.”

articles.headline: Israeli Spyware Maker Is in Spotlight Amid Reports of Wide Abuses
articles.snippet: Data leaked to a consortium of news organizations suggests that several countries use Pegasus, a powerful cyberespionage tool, to spy on rights activists, dissidents and journalists.
articles.abstract: Data leaked to a consortium of news organizations suggests that several countries use Pegasus, a powerful cyberespionage tool, to spy on rights activists, dissidents and journalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — A major Israeli cyber-surveillance company, NSO Group, came under heightened scrutiny Sunday after an international alliance of news outlets reported that governments used its software to target journalists, dissidents and opposition politicians.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: The Failure of China’s Microchip Giant Tests Beijing’s Tech Ambitions
articles.snippet: Tsinghua Unigroup, a would-be microchip champion, is facing bankruptcy, a setback in China’s quest for semiconductor self-reliance.
articles.abstract: Tsinghua Unigroup, a would-be microchip champion, is facing bankruptcy, a setback in China’s quest for semiconductor self-reliance.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2015, an obscure company run by a real estate mogul woke the world to China’s ambitions in semiconductors, the foundational technology that powers computing. Laden with state funding and political backing, the company made jaws drop with a $23 billion bid to buy the American chip maker Micron.

articles.headline: What China Expects From Businesses: Total Surrender
articles.snippet: Unlike regulators in Europe and the U.S., Beijing is using the guise of antitrust to bring powerful tech companies into line with its priorities.
articles.abstract: Unlike regulators in Europe and the U.S., Beijing is using the guise of antitrust to bring powerful tech companies into line with its priorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Pony Ma, head of the Chinese internet powerhouse Tencent, attended a group meeting with Premier Li Keqiang in 2014, he complained that many local governments had banned ride-sharing apps installed on smartphones.

articles.headline: Congratulations! It’s a Start-Up.
articles.snippet: Their friends are having babies. They’re starting companies. So why not throw a “business shower” to celebrate that life change?
articles.abstract: Their friends are having babies. They’re starting companies. So why not throw a “business shower” to celebrate that life change?
articles.lead_paragraph: Sid Singh, 36, was joking recently with a friend that everyone he knew seemed to be having their third baby while he was bringing something entirely different into the world. He had just quit his consulting job to build a financial coaching company. It dawned on him that he could have a baby shower for his new endeavor.

articles.headline: Job-Hunters, Have You Posted Your Résumé on TikTok?
articles.snippet: Feeling limited by LinkedIn, some Gen Z-ers are now applying for jobs using TikTok résumés. Employers are paying attention.
articles.abstract: Feeling limited by LinkedIn, some Gen Z-ers are now applying for jobs using TikTok résumés. Employers are paying attention.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Calling all recruiters!” Makena Yee, 21, a college student in Seattle, shouted into her camera in a recent TikTok video. “These are the reasons why you should hire me!”

articles.headline: Lost Lives, Lost Culture: The Forgotten History of Indigenous Boarding Schools
articles.snippet: Thousands of Native American children attended U.S. boarding schools designed to “civilize the savage.” Many died. Many who lived are reclaiming their identity.
articles.abstract: Thousands of Native American children attended U.S. boarding schools designed to “civilize the savage.” Many died. Many who lived are reclaiming their identity.
articles.lead_paragraph: DURANGO, Colo. — The last day Dzabahe remembers praying in the way of her ancestors was on the morning in the 1950s when she was taken to the boarding school.
articles.byline: By Rukmini Callimachi and Sharon Chischilly

articles.headline: This Train Crash Killed 49 People. It Didn’t Have to Happen.
articles.snippet: A Times investigation found that systemic failures at a government agency contributed to Taiwan’s worst rail disaster in seven decades.
articles.abstract: A Times investigation found that systemic failures at a government agency contributed to Taiwan’s worst rail disaster in seven decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — It seemed at first like a freak accident.
articles.byline: By Amy Qin, Amy Chang Chien and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: U.S. Accuses China of Hacking Microsoft
articles.snippet: The Biden administration organized a broad group of allies to condemn Beijing for cyberattacks around the world, but stopped short of taking concrete punitive steps.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration organized a broad group of allies to condemn Beijing for cyberattacks around the world, but stopped short of taking concrete punitive steps.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration for the first time on Monday accused the Chinese government of breaching Microsoft email systems used by many of the world’s largest companies, governments and military contractors, as the United States rallied a broad group of allies to condemn Beijing for cyberattacks around the world.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Virus Headwinds Hit Wall St. After Months of Smooth Sailing
articles.snippet: The S&P 500 fell as much as 2 percent, a reflection of concerns about economic growth and new restrictions on travel and tourism.
articles.abstract: The S&P 500 fell as much as 2 percent, a reflection of concerns about economic growth and new restrictions on travel and tourism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fear jolted the financial markets on Monday as investors realized that the path to global economic recovery after the pandemic would be anything but straightforward.

articles.headline: Haiti, Urged by Foreign Powers, Announces New Government
articles.snippet: Claude Joseph was the country’s leader in the aftermath of President Jovenel Moïse’s assassination. He will hand power to Ariel Henry and join a new unity government intended to keep Haiti stable.
articles.abstract: Claude Joseph was the country’s leader in the aftermath of President Jovenel Moïse’s assassination. He will hand power to Ariel Henry and join a new unity government intended to keep Haiti stable.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — With foreign powers weighing in, Haitian officials announced a new prime minister on Monday, in an attempt to resolve a caustic leadership struggle in the wake of President Jovenel Moïse’s assassination.
